Description: Floor and stemmed foot with broad resting surface of South Ionian pottery cup, probably a cup with everted rim; interior: reserved with single black circle; exterior glazed black (mostly worn and fired reddish in places); reserved on edge of foot and underside; inscription on underside.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: The lack of a rim prevents a definitive identification of the cup as a South Ionian cup with everted rim. However, the fabric and pattern find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type VIII (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Hayes' Type VIII is of the same shape as his Type IX (only the interior decoration is different) which coincides with Schlotzhauer's (Schlotzhauer 2012) Type 9a. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups also coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Johnston 2006a / Trademarks on Greek Vases: Addenda (East Greek 227)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.285) (Phase 3)
